guide.intro: UI Tokens Generator is a powerful online tool for creating a complete set of design tokens from a single base color. With this service, you can automatically generate color scales, semantic colors, and ready-to-use CSS variables for your design system.

step1.title: Step 1: Select base color
step1.description: Start by selecting a base color for your design system. Use the color picker or enter a HEX code manually. This color will be used as the foundation for generating all other tokens.

step2.title: Step 2: Generate color scale
step2.description: The tool automatically creates a color scale of 10 shades (from 50 to 900) based on the selected base color. Each shade is optimized for use in different interface components.

step3.title: Step 3: Review primary tokens
step3.description: Check the generated primary tokens: primary (base, hover, active, muted), background (background, surface, borders) and semantic (success, warning, danger). All tokens are automatically configured for optimal visual hierarchy.

step4.title: Step 4: Preview tokens

step5.title: Step 5: Export tokens
step5.description: Choose export format: CSS Variables for use in CSS, Tailwind Config for Tailwind CSS integration, or JSON for use in design systems. Copy the code with one click.

step6.title: Step 6: Integrate into project
step6.description: Copy the exported code and paste it into your project. CSS variables can be added to :root, Tailwind config to tailwind.config.js, and JSON tokens to your design system.

howTo.title: How to use UI Tokens Generator: step-by-step guide

howTo1.title: How to create design tokens from one color
howTo1.description: Select a base color using the color picker or enter a HEX code. The tool automatically generates a complete set of tokens: color scale, primary colors, background colors, and semantic colors.

howTo2.title: How to generate color scale
howTo2.description: After selecting a base color, the tool automatically creates a scale of 10 shades (50-900). Each shade is optimized for use in different component states: from lightest (50) to darkest (900).

howTo3.title: How to export tokens as CSS variables
howTo3.description: Go to the 'Export' section, select the 'CSS Variables' tab and click 'Copy'. The copied code contains all tokens in CSS variable format, ready to use in your project.

howTo4.title: How to export tokens for Tailwind CSS
howTo4.description: In the 'Export' section, select the 'Tailwind Config' tab. Copy the code and add it to the tailwind.config.js file in the theme.extend.colors section. Tokens will be available as Tailwind classes.

howTo5.title: How to create semantic colors
howTo5.description: The tool automatically generates semantic colors (success, warning, danger) based on the base color by adjusting the hue. These colors are perfect for notifications, alerts, and status indicators.

howTo6.title: How to use tokens in design system
howTo6.description: Export tokens in JSON format for use in design systems. JSON contains structured data about all colors that can be imported into design tools (Figma, Sketch) or used in code.

faq.title: Frequently asked questions about UI Tokens Generator

q1.question: What are UI tokens?
q1.answer: UI tokens are standardized design values (colors, spacing, sizes) used in design systems to ensure interface consistency. Tokens make it easy to maintain a unified style throughout the application.

q2.question: How does the token generator work?
q2.answer: The generator takes one base color and automatically creates a complete set of tokens: color scale (10 shades), primary colors (primary, hover, active), background colors, and semantic colors (success, warning, danger). All tokens are optimized for UI use.

q3.question: What export formats are supported?
q3.answer: The generator supports three export formats: CSS Variables (for use in CSS), Tailwind Config (for Tailwind CSS integration), and JSON (for use in design systems and design tools).

q4.question: How to use exported CSS variables?
q4.answer: Copy the code from the 'CSS Variables' section and add it to your stylesheet (e.g., globals.css) in the :root block. After that, you can use variables in CSS: var(--color-primary), var(--color-primary-hover), etc.

q5.question: Can I customize the color scale?
q5.answer: The color scale is automatically generated based on the base color using HSL algorithms to ensure visual consistency. Changing the base color automatically updates the entire scale.

q6.question: What are semantic colors?
q6.answer: Semantic colors are colors with specific meaning: success (green), warning (yellow/orange), danger (red). They are automatically generated based on the base color by adjusting the hue on the color wheel.

guide.title: Complete Guide to Using Color Blindness Simulator
guide.intro: Color Blindness Simulator is a powerful tool for checking the accessibility of your designs. With this service, you can see how your images and designs look to people with different types of color blindness.

step1.title: Step 1: Upload Image
step1.description: Drag and drop an image into the upload area or click 'Select File' button. Supported formats are JPG, PNG, and WEBP. After upload, the image will be displayed in preview.

step2.title: Step 2: Select Color Blindness Type
step2.description: Choose one of nine simulation types: None (original), Protanopia, Protanomaly, Deuteranopia, Deuteranomaly, Tritanopia, Tritanomaly, Achromatopsia (complete), or Achromatomaly (partial).

step3.title: Step 3: View Result
step3.description: The simulation result is displayed on canvas. You can use 'Split View' mode to view original and simulation simultaneously, or 'Compare Mode' to place them side by side.

step4.title: Step 4: Download Result
step4.description: Click 'Download Result (PNG)' button to save the simulated image to your computer. The image will be saved in PNG format.

howTo.title: How to Use Color Blindness Simulator

howTo1.title: How to Check Design for Protanopia
howTo1.description: Upload your design image and select 'Protanopia' type. This will show how the design looks to people who cannot distinguish red color. This helps ensure important information is not lost.

howTo2.title: How to Use Compare Mode
howTo2.description: Enable 'Compare Mode' to view original and simulated images side by side simultaneously. This allows you to easily see differences and evaluate how accessible your design is.

howTo3.title: How to Use Split View
howTo3.description: Enable 'Split View' to display original on the left and simulation on the right in one image. This is useful for quick comparison without switching between modes.

howTo4.title: How to Check for Complete Color Blindness
howTo4.description: Select 'Achromatopsia' type to simulate complete color blindness. This will show how your design looks in shades of gray, helping ensure important information is conveyed not only by color.

howTo5.title: How to Download Result
howTo5.description: After applying simulation, click 'Download Result (PNG)' button. The image will be saved to your computer in PNG format and can be used for documentation or presentations.

howTo6.title: How to Check Web Design for Accessibility
howTo6.description: Take a screenshot of your web design and upload it to the simulator. Check all color blindness types to ensure important elements (buttons, links, warnings) are distinguishable for all users.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions About Color Blindness Simulator

q1.question: What color blindness types are supported?
q1.answer: Simulator supports 9 types: None (original), Protanopia (cannot see red), Protanomaly (weak red vision), Deuteranopia (cannot see green), Deuteranomaly (weak green vision), Tritanopia (cannot see blue), Tritanomaly (weak blue vision), Achromatopsia (complete color blindness), and Achromatomaly (partial color blindness).

q2.question: How does simulation work?
q2.answer: Simulation uses color transformation matrices (3x3) that are applied to each pixel of the image. These matrices are based on standard color vision deficiency simulation algorithms and accurately reproduce how people with color blindness see colors.

q3.question: Can I use it to check web design?
q3.answer: Yes, simulator is perfect for checking web design accessibility. Take a screenshot of your design and upload it to the simulator to see how it looks to people with different types of color blindness.

q4.question: What is protanopia?
q4.answer: Protanopia is a type of color blindness where a person cannot distinguish red color. This is the most common type of color blindness, affecting approximately 1% of the male population.

q5.question: What is deuteranopia?
q5.answer: Deuteranopia is a type of color blindness where a person cannot distinguish green color. This is also a common type of color blindness, often confused with protanopia.

q6.question: What is achromatopsia?
q6.answer: Achromatopsia is complete color blindness where a person sees only shades of gray. This is a rare type of color blindness, but checking design for this type helps ensure important information does not depend only on color.

q7.question: Can I download the result?
q7.answer: Yes, you can download the simulated image in PNG format by clicking 'Download Result (PNG)' button. This is useful for documentation, presentations, or sharing with your team.

q8.question: Why use compare mode?
q8.answer: Compare mode allows you to see original and simulated images side by side simultaneously. This helps easily evaluate differences and understand which design elements may be problematic for people with color blindness.
